Based on my search, I found comprehensive information about Tom Sawyer's literary impact, influence on children's literature, and its role in establishing the American boy archetype. Here's what the search revealed:

## Literary Impact and Influence

The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, together with The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, changed the course of children's literature in the United States as well as of American literature generally, presenting the first deeply felt portrayal of boyhood.(no content)More than any other work in our culture, it established America's vision of childhood.(no content)The book sold slowly at first but has since become the archetypal comic novel of American childhood.

## American Boy Archetype

Tom Sawyer's main character is considered the epitome of the all-American boy, full of mischief but basically purehearted.(no content)Mark Twain created two fictional boys, Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn, who still seem more real than most of the people we know. In a still puritanical nation, Twain reminded adults that children were not angels, but fellow human beings, and perhaps all the more lovable for their imperfections and bad grooming.

## Cultural Legacy

The characters--Tom himself, Becky Thatcher, Huck Finn, Injun Joe, and Aunt Polly--have become part of our American heritage.(no content)Many of the scenes are familiar and have become a part of our cultural heritage: Consider for example, the scene in which Tom manipulates others to paint a fence he himself was to have painted, the scene with Tom and Becky lost in the cave, and the scene of the boys in the graveyard.

## Mark Twain's Broader Literary Impact

Mark Twain's impact on American literature and culture is significant and far-reaching. Twain's use of humor and satire to address serious issues helped to shape American identity and establish a tradition of social commentary in American literature.(no content)We can see his legacy in the works of writers such as Ernest Hemingway and William Faulkner, who were influenced by Twain's use of language and his ability to capture the essence of American life.

## Universal Appeal

The appeal of the novel lies mostly in Twain's ability to capture--or re-capture--universal experiences and dreams and fears of childhood.(no content)Reading Tom Sawyer today is an invitation to talk about how American childhood has and hasn't changed—and also to laugh at Twain's enduring invention of a great American comic voice.

The search results demonstrate that Tom Sawyer has had an enduring impact on American literature, establishing fundamental archetypes and contributing to the development of a distinctly American literary voice that continues to influence writers and readers today.
